title: How much will the interest rate on my car change in a chapter 13?
question: I have a CalPers Pension net is 2408 a month. I have SSDI 2150 a month.
answers: Hi there. The interest rate on your auto loan will not be reduced automatically by the filing of the bankruptcy. In fact, you would not be permitted to lower the interest through a cram down in the chapter 13 plan as you have purchased the car recently. However, your attorney may be able to negotiate a lower interest rate with the lender after filing. So you should explore this option before turning the vehicle back in. In terms of how this will affect your trustee payment, it largely depends on whether your annualized income exceeds the median for the sate. If yes, then having no car payment will increase your trustee payment significantly as you would not be able to claim auto ownership cost. My recommendation would be to replace this vehicle with another with a lower payment. This way, you can still claim auto ownership cost and hopefully lower your monthly payment to the trustee. However, I agree that chapter 13 matters are more complicated and you should consult an attorney before filing. Good luck!
While when you purchased the car can be important, in NC vehicles are typically repaid at 5.25% in a 13. So yes, it could lower the interest you end up paying the car lender.

In a well crafted Chapter 13 Plan your interest rate will go down to what is referred to as the"Till" rate. Most attorneys think that is prime rate + 2% or a total of 5.25% interest. Actually, knowing and truly understanding the "Till" case which really is about the prime rate (3.25%) plus a "risk factor" which in Till was determined to be 2%. I and other attorneys regularly get plans approved at 3.25% + only 1.5% for risk factor to be a total 4.75%. It is not unusual to get 4.5%. This is where you want someone who understands what the case really says and how the judges are going to interpret the law.

At any rate, your paying 22% interest will end no matter what the situation is.

Another thing to understand is that what interest is paid on is the VALUE of the car. Anything above that is paid in full but with 0% interest. Yes, that is no interest at all on the debt above the value of the car.

Since you have a purchase money loan on the vehicle and it is less than 910 days since the purchase you will have to pay the debt in full or surrender the vehicle.

Whether or not you keep the vehicle will be something to look at when all the math is considered.

As to the amount of your payment increasing or decreasing to the trustee will depend on many factors such as your specific situation, means test, income etc. These are too complex to try to go over here.

What you need to understand is that trying to do a Chapter 13 plan without a highly competent attorney who has been doing Chapter 13 cases is suicide. The success rates for Chapter 13 cases are not that high and are 0% without attorney representation. The Chapter 13 national trustee website had an article that was captioned "Chapter 13 + self representation = 0 success rate"

I would HIGHLY recommend that you find competent bankruptcy counsel in the Sacramento area that knows 1. how to do Chapter 13 cases; knows the Judges; and 3. has a track record of successful Chapter 13 plans.

I would recommend you find a quality bankruptcy attorney by looking at Avvo's ratings for Sacramento attorneys.

You could also look at the CA State bar website for a Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist in Sacramento. Most attorneys will give you are free initial consultation. I have provided a link to the state bar below.

Another potential source for finding a good attorney would be through a search of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys (NACBA.org) to find a good local attorney. Again, I have provided a link below.

There is a new ratings website that ranks over 70 different "top rated Sacramento bankruptcy attorneys" using a number of different criteria. This website leaves a lot to be desired in looks, but it has a sort-able database that gives you 20+/- different options to sort the attorneys based on what you think are the most important. It apparently does not accept advertising from attorneys. I have included the link below.

The interest rate can go down to around 5.25% but there is no way to tell what your plan payment will be without going through your budget and your assets with an attorney. Chapter 13 bankruptcy can be complicated so I suggest that you call an attorney for a consultation.

If you craft your Chapter 13 Plan correctly, you can lower your interest rate on the vehicle if your plan calls for paying the vehicle inside the plan. Regardless of when you purchased the vehicle, you can always propose a lower interest rate on a vehicle. Nothing happens automatically. In the alternative, if you surrender the vehicle, all of your disposable income still has to be pledged, so your plan payment will not automatically go down to allow you to save that money. You will still have to comply with the applicable commitment period and the amount due as the end result of the B-22C. I have attached a link to some instructions for your review

Your BK atty can sometimes negotiate an interest rate reduction as part of his/her representation. If successful, the lender files a proof of claim for the secured part of its debt and any excess balance over the value of the vehicle can be filed as unsecured at zero interest. More information is needed to give you useful advice. What is the value/condition of the vehicle? If you have little or no equity in the car, now is the time to surrender it. BK 13 is not a DIY project. Click the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer". Many offer a free consultation.

Chapter 13 will not lower the interest rate on a car unless the car was purchased 2.5 years before the filing of chapter 13. The chapter 13 plan payment is determined by many factors. Returning the car would not automatically increase your plan payment. Chapter 13 is not a DIY project.
